Determine the mass of sulphur (IV) oxide obtained when 91.0g of oxygen reacts completely with sulphur according to the following equation: S(s) + O\(_2\)(g) → SO\(_2\)(g) [S = 32; O = 16]
explanation:
S + O\(_2\) → SO\(_2\).
According to the equation 32g of O\(_2\) produced 64g of SO\(_2\)
therefore 91g of O2 will produce yg of SO2y = \(\frac{91 * 64}{32}\)
y = 182g of SO\(_2\)

X\(_2\)(g) + 3Y\(_2\)(g) ⇌ 2XY\(_3\)(g); ∆H = xKJmol\(^{-1}\)

options.A: the yield of XY 3 will decompose
options.D: the forward reaction will remain static

explanation: Increase in temperature will cause the forward reaction to occur, increasing the amounts of the products and decreasing the amounts of reactants.

text: What is the expression for the equilibrium constant (Kc) for the following reaction? N2(g) + O2(g) ⇌ 2NO(g)

Equal amounts of marble chips are reacted separately with 100cm3 of hydrochloric acid of different concentrations. If all the marble chips reacted; which of the following remained the same in each case?

options.A: Average rate of evoluton of gas
options.B: Total mass of gas evolved during the reaction
options.C: Time taken for the reaction to reach completion

explanation: The total mass of gas evolved during the reaction will remain the same in each case. This is because the amount of marble chips is the same in each case, and the reaction goes to completion. Therefore, the same amount of gas will be produced in each case, regardless of the concentration of the hydrochloric acid.

Consider the following equation: Cr\(_2\)O\(_7\)\(^{2-}\)(aq) + 14H\(^+\)(aq) + 6e\(^-\) → 2Cr\(^{3+}\)(ag) + 7H\(_2\)O(1). The oxidation number of chromium changes from
explanation:
Cr\(_2\)O\(_7\)\(^{2-}\)(aq) + 14H\(^+\)(aq) + 6e\(^-\) → 2Cr\(^{3+}\)(ag) + 7H\(_2\)O(1).
All we need to do is to calculate the oxidation number of Cr on the reactant side (LHS) and compare with the one on the RHS.
Cr\(_2\)O\(_7\)\(^{2-}\)     →    Cr\(^{3+}\)
Cr\(_2\)O\(_7\) = - 2         →    Cr  = + 3
2Cr + 7(O) = - 2
2Cr + 7(- 2) = - 2
2Cr - 14  = - 2
2Cr = - 2 + 14
2Cr = + 12
Cr = \(\frac{12}{2}\)
Cr = + 6    →      Cr  = + 3
Therefore, the change in oxidation number of Cr changed from +6 to +3 - Option C

text: Which of the following types of alkanols undergo oxidation to produce alkanoic acids? I. Primary alkanols  II. Secondary alkanols III. Tertiary alkanols
explanation:
Primary alkanols undergo oxidation to yield Alkanoic acid or Aldehyde depending on the conditions.
Secondary alkanols undergo oxidation to yield Ketones, while
Tertiary alkanols do not mostly undergo oxidation.
